_description: John Lydgate, ‘Consulo quisque eris’ — fifteen 8-line stanzas

BodArcSelB10.First Lines:
I Counsayll what so euyr thou beOf polycye foresyght and
                    prudence…
BodArcSelB10.Last Lines:
…Bytwene vyce and vertue to sett a dyfferenceTo his pleasaunce
                    to vttre oure language
BodArcSelB10.Attributed Title:
‘Consulo quisquis eris qui pacis sedera queris / Consonus
                        esto lupis cum quibus esse cupis’ (f. 205)

BodAsh59.First Lines:
COvnuseyllier where þat ever þou beOf plolicye for sight
                    and prudenceIf þou wolt lyve in peese and vnyteeConfidde þy
                    self and thenke on þis sentence…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…Twene vyce and vertue to sette a differenceTo his plesaunce
                    so graunte oure pilgrimage
BodAsh59.Attributed Author:
made by þe Munke of Bury cleped Johan Lidegate (f.
                    29v)
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
Here foloweþe a poetycal balade of wysdame made by þe Munke of
                    Bury cleped Johan Lidegate (f. 29v)

CULHh412.First Lines:
I Counsell what so euer thow beOff polycye forsight and
                    prudence…
CULHh412.Last Lines:
…Twene vice and vertu to set a differenceTo hys plesaunce to
                    vttyr owre langage
CULHh412.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Political, Religious and Love Poems, from Lambeth MS. 306 and other
                sources.
EETS
         o.s. 15 (1866); repr. 1962; rev. ed. 1903: 46-55.

CamJes56.First Lines:
[I] Counsail what so euere þu beOf policye for sight and
                    prudene…
CamJes56.Last Lines:
…Twene vice and vertu to set a differenceTo his plesaunce to
                    vttir his language
CamJes56.Attributed Title:
Consulo quisque eris qui pacis federa queris / Conlonus esto lupis cum
                        quibus esse cupis (f. 22v)

CamTCC601.First Lines:
I counseyle the what so euer thow beOf Polycy for syght &
                    prudence…
CamTCC601.Last Lines:
…Twene vyces and vertu to set a dyfferenceTo hys plesuance and
                    vtter hys langage
CamTCC601.Note:
Fifteen stanzas, including 8-stanza ‘Verba
                    translatoris’ all with the same last word, ‘langage.’
                    Latin couplet, ‘Concilio quisquis egis quis pacis…’
                    added by a later hand to top margin, f. 296v.

BLHar2251.First Lines:
I counceile what so euer thow beOf pollicye foresight and
                    prudence…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Atwene vice and vertu to set a differenceTo his plesaunce to
                    vtter his langage
BLHar2251.Attributed Title:
Concilio quisque eris qui pacis fidem queris / Consonus esto lupis cum
                        quibus esse cupis (f. 11v)

BLHar2255.First Lines:
I Conseyl what so euyr thou beOff policye forsight and
                    prudence…
BLHar2255.Last Lines:
…Tween vice and vertu to sette a differenceTo his plesaunce to
                    vttren our language Explicit
BLHar2255.Attributed Title:
Consulo quisque eris qui pacis federa queris / Consonus esto lupis cum
                        quibus esse cupis (in rubric, f. 1)
BLHar2255.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Political, Religious and Love Poems, from Lambeth MS. 306 and other
                sources.
EETS
         o.s. 15 (1866); repr. 1962; rev. ed. 1903: 46-55.
Halliwell-Phillipps,  James Orchard,
                        ed.  
             A Selection from the Minor Poems of Don John Lydgate.
Percy Society
         2. London: T. Richard, 1840: 173-8.
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS
         o.s. 192 (1934); repr. 1961: 750-4.

BLAdd34360.First Lines:
I counceile what so uer thow beOf policye forsight and
                    prudence…
BLAdd34360.Last Lines:
…Atwene vice & vertu to set a differenceto his
                    plesaunce to vtter his langage
BLAdd34360.Attributed Title:
Concilio quisquis eris qui pacis fidem queris / Consonus esto lupis cum
